author: Okmanl
body:
I think it's just a vocal minority (mostly redditors) who despise Bezos. The vast majority of people probably don't care. Also I personally think that Bezos has contributed more to society than people give him credit for.

* Pioneered cloud computing almost a decade before any of the other tech giants (Google, Microsoft).
* Reduced the total carbon foot print of the US. It’s a lot cheaper for people to order online rather than drive a 2-ton vehicle across the earth everytime they need to buy a carton of milk.
* Has given people a lot of their time back that they would’ve had to spend running errands like grocery shopping. That extra 3-4 hours saved every week and reinvested wisely can compound into something life changing for a lot of people.
* Spends 1 billion every year to help advance space travel via Blue Origin.
* Has employed over 2 million people with a company-wide minimum wage of $18/hr and good health benefits. Amazon’s net profits in 2020 was around 21 billion dollars. They pay their employees 90 billion dollars in wages and other benefits.
* Yeah Amazon’s founder has 180bn net worth. But by founding and spearheading Amazon, he also created \~1.6 trillion dollars worth of wealth for other people (Amazon’s total market cap is at 1.8 trillion dollars).  


&#x200B;

Lastly, the federal government has a budget of 4 trillion dollars per YEAR. If we forced Amazon’s founder to redistribute his wealth it would be enough to run the country for 2 weeks at best. Overall him accumulating \~180 bn over a lifetime is a small price to pay for the value Amazon and potentially Blue Origin has provided and will provide in the future.

author: Baraxton
body:
Apple, Microsoft, and the other FANGMAN names dominate and will continue to do so even in recessionary times as we’ve learned over the past year. A crash likely will not change that. Using LEAPS calls to create synthetic positions using a fraction of the amount of money required to purchase the underlying stock is a great way to maintain upside, while simultaneously limiting downside. 

A good discussion on why a market crash is unlikely to occur as well as the strategy mentioned above can be found here: https://youtu.be/egxpHn-ez0c

author: plainbread11
body:
P&G. Nice dividend. 

TGT got oversold big time.

Walmart is going to become even bigger. Check out their recent GoLocal launch. They’re diversifying their revenue streams away from just in store activity.

Costco (unfortunately a bit pricey for me). BJ’s may be an alternative— a smaller club chain (I have a few shares).

I’m actually slightly bullish on Macy’s only because their move to ecommerce/click and collect has been pretty good. Don’t have any shares yet though. 

GE possibly. I don’t have any myself, but the new CEO previously led Danaher. They’re selling off terrible divisions or closing them, and look to be trying to consolidate their position. Read Lights Out by Thomas Gryta to get an in-depth look at the company.

Albertsons— second largest grocer in the US, e-commerce is great. 

MSFT— no question here. Decent dividend, decent performance, continues to grow.

AAPL— interesting to see their further revenue diversification as they move into cars.

J&J and Abbott— both good companies. Don’t have any J&J, but I have Abbott. Nice steady performance, never too much price fluctuation, and dividends are good.

author: StereotypedCrocodile
body:
As CEO, Ballmer presided over ME, Vista, the Zune, Windows Phone, and Windows Mobile. All failures. 

His first major effort was to push away from the company’s traditional PC-first strategy. Throughout his tenure, MSFT’s profits were sustained by the traditional Windows and Office PC offerings. MSFT’s stock price stagnated during his tenure. 

Literally every single thing he did failed and the only reason MSFT survived was because of the things he wanted to move away from. 

All of MSFT’s recent success has been the work of Satya Nadella. His main pathway to success has been to do the opposite of Ballmer in every possible way. 

So what we see here is an incompetent CEO reacting incompetently.

author: pashacay
body:
This is bs. Wash sale doesn't work like that. If you have a loss and buy the stock back, you won't get to claim the loss. But it doesn't make you pay tax on profit you haven't made

https://www.investopedia.com/terms/w/washsalerule.asp

"For example, consider the case of an investor who purchased 100 shares of Microsoft for $33, sold the shares at $30, and within 30 days bought 100 shares at $32. In this case, while the loss of $300 would be disallowed by the IRS because of the wash-sale rule, it can be added to the $3,200 cost of the new purchase. The new cost basis, therefore, becomes $3,500 for the 100 shares that were purchased the second time, or $35 per share."

author: decisions4me
body:
Once Elon makes a 4 door sedan with 500 mile per charge range and a million mile battery lifetime, and for under $25,000. 

If the Model T from Ford were superior to horses in cost and performance, the first the electric engine to replace the internal combustion engine, it is going to  need to be better in cost and performance. 

That said, there is SpaceX and StarLink. And the Boring company. And also Neuralink. All these have potential to improve the quality of life on earth and generate more total resources for society at a faster rate. 

But the key is technology and an environment that can accept that innovation. 

It’s a bit surprising that there are around 3000 billionaires in the world and yet Elon Musk is spearheading over half of the most promising and innovative solutions to increase the average quality of the human condition. 

There are only so many resources in society. TSLA getting bigger just means it has ownership of more resources or is seen as such. 

I think that because TSLA touched 880 but couldn’t touch 900, then 1,000 is far away, as is 1,500. A price rejection of that significance without changes in many of the fundamental underlying factors of the company suggest that, well, many things will need to severely change for TSLA to rise up that high. 

Finance is the way resources flow in society to incentive activities towards their most profitable outcomes. 

With the amount of shares TSLA has printed, is it worth 1500? Especially if humanity does have a technological leap - is there enough room for society? If TSLA has technological leaps, that will transfer to other industries. 

SpaceX could acquire hundreds of trillions every month in space extraction resources for humanity 
StarLink can replace Comcast 
What Microsoft did with offering an easy user interface system and computer operating system, Neuralink will do even more. An ultra-high bandwidth computer interface system. If sandals applied to feet improve walking performance, And a computer improves thinking performance much like a sandal improves walking performance, then Neuralink is a Tesla. 

Do you realize that of technological leaps happen, it might not push the price of TSLA too high? It’s already priced in to be successful. 

Basically. $1500 Maybe under 5 years? 

That’s the issue with TSLA. They outperformance many times and they are expected to outperform technologically. TSLA having success is more likely to push other sectors to outperform, but not necessarily TSLA. Basically, what if it is likely for a potential initial public offering of Neuralink and SpaceX to triple within two years? Would TSLA still be a decent option? It’s about relative growth. And TSLA is already assumed to be capable at fulfilling the scenario of the electric engine replacing most internal combustion engines within 20 years. And their current price reflects that. 

A share price evaluation of 1500 needs… society to make changes. And even then, if a share price of 1500 happens without monumental shifts in society due to technological leaps, there will be other options with higher relative growth as a result.

author: MushroomCake28
body:
Overvalued? Probably. But that's just an opinion, might be totally undervalued.

Same as dot-com bubble? Probably not.

Back then there tons of shit company with no profits. Today, the big techs are all solid companies with profits and a shit ton of assets. They are good companies that are just trading very high, unlike bad companies that are trading at insane prices like back then. Don't get me wrong, there are still overpriced shit companies, but the big companies that form the bigger part of tech funds, and even the SP 500 as a whole, are mostly good companies.

So is a correction coming? Maybe. Personally I would say probably, but who knows.

A crash like 2008? Maybe.

But is Google/Apple/Microsoft/FB and all the other big tech companies going bankrupt? Almost certainly not. Their price might fall, but I highly doubt they'll go bankrupt.

If there is a crisis, I would be much worried about other companies, not the big tech. Like, do you know how much cash they have? I'm not even kidding, like they have billions and billions of cash on hand.  Paying down their "low" level of debt (relative to their size and profts) will not be an issue even if there's a crisis. I would be much more worried about companies with lots of debt and not enough liquidity to pay their bills if you're wary of a crisis.

Let's say worse case scenario, there's a huge crash. I'm ready to bet that in 20 years the price of the market will be much higher than it is now.

TLDR: Buy an index fund -> Forget about it -> Profit (and sleep soundly at night)

author: doducduy96
body:
I buy VOO every month with 40% of my income. Whenever I feel anxious about my position, I take a deep breath, a day off and go for a walk/drive around town. When I walkout of the door, a AMZN package I ordered 18 hours ago had already been here, neat. Then I take out my AAPL phone and go to GOOGL to look for a place to eat/chill, just got my PFE vaccine last month so I’m good to go. Hoping into my trust worthy F F150 and starting to drive, I notice that hmmm I have been seeing a lot of TSLA cars around, maybe it’ll be my next car? I’m daydreaming. The drive is 5 miles, I wonder why the HDs, COSTs, WMTs, TGTs parking are always packed like that, even tho it’s only Wednesday, 
Hmmm guess I’ll skip groceries today. I feel lazy. Sitting at the restaurant’s outdoor patio, I enjoy my brunch with a glass of wine, my eyes start wandering around. What a beautiful day, the birds, the air, the people. Maybe it’s enough wine for the day, I go in to grab a soft drink. 8 out of 10 drinks on the fountain machine are KO products. Lots people around me are working on their AAPL and MSFT laptops. They are so thin yet very powerful. As a tech geek I know they are powered by INTC and AMD CPUs, and the heavy stuffs are done with NVIDIA GPUs. Gosh people are so productive nowadays! It’s time to leave, I lay my JPM V card to the tray, 5x points for dining baby! 5 mins later I’m on my way. Shit, I’m almost out of gas, pulling into a CVX gas station, tap my BAC MA card because I’ll get 3% cash back on Gas. Damn there’s a line wrapping around that MCD and SBUX drive thru, the food is unhealthy but well business is still booming I guess. 
Getting back into my home, I suddenly remember tomorrow is Oct 1st. I have T, VZ, NFLX bills to pay. 
Damn, I observed a lot from my lazy day today. I wonder what my life would be without all of the conveniences I saw today. 
I log into my Fidelity account and buy 4 more VOO shares. 
Feeling good.

Warren & Charlie on EBITDA:

>  The number of times we're going to buy into a company where people are talking about EBITDA is roughly zero. If we take all the people in the world who have talked about EBITDA and those who haven't, there'll be plenty more frauds in the first group … 

> Look at companies like Wal-Mart, GE and Microsoft — they’ll never use EBITDA in their annual report.

> People who use EBITDA are either trying to con you or they’re conning themselves. Telecoms, for example, spend every dime that’s coming in. Interest and taxes are real costs.

Microsoft was considered a steal at 200 last year but was barely talked about compared to Apple. Amazon was considered overvalued at 3k last year but is now considered quite cheap considering how well they've done. Not sure about Netflix.

FWIW, I consult for some pretty big household name companies, and they were using zoom long before pandemic (long before trump even killed off our early warning and response systems even)

They used it because it just... worked.  These companies have huge embedded Microsoft and Cisco and Google enterprises.  But for super easy, bug free video calls, they used zoom.  It was no headaches.

I'd argue that aspect still exists.  These days there's always people saying "i can't used X, or Y doesn't work on my device". But everybody seems copacetic with zoom.

Early last week, Zerohedge said it was the start of the apocalypse and then Msft did a share buyback and Zerohedge (and his lemming sheep fans) complained it was a conspiracy theory to stop the collapse and ruin his thesis. Imagine thinking that a share buy back by one of the best blue chip companies could ruin your thesis of impending apocalypse. If it was that easy, then your theory was weak to begin with.

body:
Not medically educated, but from what I have been hearing the mRNA can be repurposed for different situation pretty quickly. I'd imagine we'll have a vaccine for the mu variant faster than we had for the first vaccine now that we got the mRNA method working. The slow down would probably with the FDA approval, but testing multiple steps simultaneously is now tried, so I'd imagine that would go faster as well.  
I think they had that delta specific vaccine ready to be tested pretty quickly(though it wasn't even necessary), so I'd imagine we'll have something pretty quick for mu if it turns out to be a serious threat.

author: I_know_nothing_42
body:
MU's earnings are in 24 days. 

Expect vol to increase, place the trade then. If bearish sell the call spreads. It already took a hit in early august for supply issues. Selling the call spread is a little bit easier to predict what you'll make. If you buy a put spread, the vol collapse and the spread having to go fully ITM to realize a full gain has more variables at work. You can buy the put spread and still lose even with having the direction right.

Working myself out of a put that is ITM right now.

I'm looking to get out next week and waiting until earnings to put new positions on.  

I wouldn't be betting against MU just because spot prices are falling. That means supply chains are working their way out and that they will be producing at capacity vs charging a little bit more per diminished output. They can actually make more money overall at lower prices. This will be a quicker price recovery than the 2011 Fukushima earthquake. Demand is not going away.

author: toydan
body:
Well i didnt even think i would trade much of anything today.  Changed my mind, as i have to leverage more into this bull run

* Closed out of put debit spread on LCID for a small gain.  Not my nature, but glad i executed the strategy. if drops again i will sell CSPs on margin w it
* bought $MU to get to 100 sh.  It is now a boomer play for me w dividend announcement.  Will sell CCs once it hits $85.
* Bought ABNB 1/23 LEAPS @ $49.50.  Trying to keep more options in retirement accounts v nonQ for tax reasons.  sold some TCNNF and a tiny bit of SOFI to make work.  was eating at me not be in this one
* AMZN 3670/3665 9/10 put credit spreads  Falling in love w this strategy.  i like weeklies and this is a 7% return 250%ish annualized.  .12 delta (88% chance of success).  I use 2-3 standard deviations on 3 month Bollinger for entry points.  Theta on this is a juicy 1.30. I will let you know the first time i ever have one of these not work. Going to play these on NVDA too i decided.
* $AAL 9/10 $19.50 CSP on margin $.33.  I have played zero airlines, hotels, cruise lines for 18 months. Think this a good play assigned or not.  CSPs have been printing like a MoFo 

That is all.  Hope your day is great and your runway long!

author: Zach9559
body: MU. It’s the epitome of a value stock - right now it’s trading at a forward PE of 6.5! As of Friday, it closed at $73.81. The average analyst price target? $115. That’s a 55% upside - earnings are expected to double next year. Also, Li Lu and Mohnish Pabrai have 50% of their clients assets in it - nearly $1B for Li Lu. Every other value investor you can think of has a meaningful stake in it; David Tepper, Guy Spier, Seth Klarman, Stan Druckenmiller, the list goes on. At this price it’s a steal, and once investors get the bad taste of 2018 out of their mouth, it will take off like a rocket.
